articles.title: India, China to account for half of global growth in 2023: IMF
articles.article:
The International Monetary Fund (IMF) managing director Kristalina Georgiva said that India and China are expected to account for half of the global growth in 2023. She added that the world economy is expected to grow at lower than 3 per cent this year.

"Some momentum comes from emerging economies Asia especially is a bright spot. India and China are expected to account for half of the global growth in 2023. But others face a steeper climb," Georgieva told the news agency PTI.

She further warned that a sharp slowdown in the world economy last year triggered by the COVID-19 pandemic and the Russia-Ukraine war could linger on this year as well. The Russia-Ukraine crisis led to the global growth rate in 2022 dropping by almost half from 6.1 per cent to 3.4 per cent, Georgieva added.

But for how long is this slow growth phase going to last? The IMF boss believes that the phase of slower economic activity will be prolonged as the next five years will witness less than 3 per cent growth. This, according to the IMF chief, is “our lowest medium-term growth forecast since 1990, and well below the average of 3.8 per cent from the past two decades.”

She added that slower growth will make it more challenging for the low-income countries to catch up. She explained, “Poverty and hunger could further increase, a dangerous trend that was started by the COVID crisis.”

Georgieva added that lower-income countries will be crippled with high borrowing costs at a time of weakening demand for their exports. She also noted that about 90 per cent of advanced economies are projected to witness a decline in growth rates in 2023.

Talking about the banking crisis, Georgieva said while the global banking system had “come a long way” since the 2008 crisis, “concerns remain about vulnerabilities that may be hidden, not just at banks but also non-banks.”

"Now is not the time for complacency," she said while signing off.

articles.title: SUMMARY OF THE UNION BUDGET 2023-24
articles.article:
In the 75th year of India’s Independence, the World has recognized the Indian Economy as a ‘bright star’ as the Economic Growth is estimated at 7 per cent, which is the highest among all major economies, in spite of the massive global slowdown caused by COVID-19 and Russia-Ukraine War. This was stated by Union Minister for Finance & Corporate Affairs Smt. Nirmala Sitharaman, while presenting the Union Budget 2023-24 in Parliament today. She emphasized that Indian economy is on the right track, and despite a time of challenges, heading towards a bright future.

Smt. Sitharaman said that this Budget hopes to build on the foundation laid in the previous Budget, and the blueprint drawn for India@100, which envisions a prosperous and inclusive India, where the fruits of development reach all regions and citizens, especially our youth, women, farmers, OBCs, Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes, and where every person has the opportunity to shape his/her own destiny, free from fear and want.

To achieve this vision, the Finance Minister said that a new wave of reforms will be ushered in, which will strengthen various sectors of the economy, the social fabric of the Nation, and the spirit of Antyodaya embedded in our culture. She said that India, while keeping its traditions, customs and ethos intact, will emerge as a global powerhouse that harnesses technology and digital revolution, thereby scaling new heights in every field, contributing to global good, and remaining firmly committed to peace. Smt. Sitharaman expressed confidence that this Budget will fulfil the aspirations and expectations of all stakeholders, be it our farmer brethren, youth, entrepreneurs, industry, international investors or honest taxpayers.

The Union Minister said that this Budget seeks to catalyse economic growth and enhance the overall wellbeing of every Indian, which, in turn, will boost India’s national spirit. She said that the Government led by Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi is committed to fulfilling the dreams of all, and the Budget reflects the vision of our Government to position India as the most attractive investment destination.

articles.title: India's Services Sector Rebounds at Record Rate
articles.article:
India's services sector has rebounded at a record rate in the three months from April to June despite the onslaught of the COVID-19 pandemic. The services sector, which includes various industries such as retail, hotels, transportation, and communication, among others, is a key driver of India's economy. The remarkable recovery of the sector has contributed significantly to the country's economic growth.

According to data released by the Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation, the services sector grew at a record rate of 12.4% during the said period. This impressive growth rate comes despite the challenges posed by the second wave of COVID-19 during those months. It indicates the resilience of the Indian economy and the adaptability of businesses in coping with the pandemic's impact.

The services sector's revival is a positive sign for India as it seeks to overcome the adverse effects of the pandemic. It not only provides a much-needed boost to the economy but also indicates the gradual recovery of the overall business environment in the country. The growth in the services sector is expected to create more job opportunities and further drive economic activities across various related industries.

As the pandemic's impact continues to wane, it is crucial for the government and businesses to sustain this positive momentum and foster an environment that enables the services sector to thrive. Additionally, focusing on technological advancements and digitalization can further enhance the sector's growth prospects and make it more resilient to future challenges.

The government's role in providing necessary support, implementing favorable policies, and ensuring a conducive business environment will be vital in ensuring the sustained growth of India's services sector. By leveraging the sector's potential, India can solidify its position as a robust and dynamic economy in the post-pandemic world.

articles.title: RBI Raises Interest Rates Amidst Surging Inflation
articles.article:
In response to the surging inflation and rising concerns over the Indian economy's stability, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has raised its key interest rates by 0.75 percentage point, bringing it to 5.75%. This is the highest interest rate in the country in the past five years.

The decision to hike interest rates comes as the RBI aims to combat the soaring inflation, which has been a cause for worry among policymakers and citizens alike. The increasing prices of essential goods and services have put a strain on households and disrupted economic activities.

The RBI has taken a proactive stance to curb inflation and stabilize the economy. While the move may have an impact on borrowing costs and investment decisions in the short term, it is a necessary step to address the inflationary pressures and maintain financial stability.

However, it is worth noting that the central bank's action has raised concerns among some industry experts and businesses. They worry that higher interest rates could lead to decreased consumer spending and reduced demand, affecting industries that are already grappling with the pandemic's repercussions.

The RBI also revised its GDP growth forecast for the current fiscal year, predicting a slower growth rate of 6.3% due to the inflationary challenges. The bank emphasized the need for coordinated efforts from both the government and monetary authorities to address the economic situation effectively.

Amidst the tightening monetary policy, the RBI assured that it would closely monitor the economic developments and take necessary actions as required. The central bank remains committed to managing inflation and fostering a conducive economic environment for sustainable growth in the long run.

articles.title: India and ASEAN Discuss Trade and Economic Partnership
articles.article:
India and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) recently held discussions on strengthening trade and economic partnership between the two regions. The virtual meeting involved representatives from India and all ten ASEAN member countries.

The discussions primarily focused on boosting economic ties and enhancing cooperation in areas such as trade, investment, technology, and tourism. India and ASEAN have long-standing economic relations, and both parties aim to leverage each other's strengths to foster growth and development.

During the meeting, various potential areas of collaboration were explored, including the promotion of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in both regions, which play a crucial role in job creation and economic growth.

The leaders also deliberated on the need to address non-tariff barriers and simplify trade processes to facilitate smoother movement of goods and services between India and ASEAN countries. Additionally, discussions on harnessing the potential of the digital economy and e-commerce were also part of the agenda.

India and ASEAN's economic partnership holds significant promise as it can open up new opportunities and markets for businesses, drive innovation, and strengthen regional economic resilience. By working together, both parties can overcome shared challenges and collectively address global issues.

As the world continues to navigate the uncertainties brought about by the pandemic and geopolitical shifts, collaborations like these can help in reinforcing economic stability and promoting inclusive growth.

India's engagement with ASEAN is a crucial part of its broader 'Act East' policy, which aims to deepen economic and strategic ties with Southeast Asian nations. By building strong partnerships and leveraging regional cooperation, India can enhance its economic presence in the region and contribute to its overall prosperity.
